Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant frequency. We examine the effect of an integral transformation defined by \\( T[f(t)] = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st} f(t) dt \\), widely known as the Laplace transform, applied to the function over time.

If after applying the Laplace transform to \\( z(t) \\), an intervention modifies the transform by a factor \\( (s - a)^{-1} \\), will the time-domain behavior of the modified function depend solely on the frequency \\( \\omega \\) of the original function?
Explanation: The intervention alters the transform, affecting its inverse and thus the behavior of the resulting time-domain function. The final function becomes a convolution of \\( e^{i\\omega t} \\) and \\( e^{at} \\), making the behavior dependent on both \\( \\omega \\) and the intervention parameter \\( a \\).
